title: Adding a function that appends to an association only if the records do not exist
body:
It's often the case that when you have an association and you only want to append an ActiveRecord object to the association if that association does not already hold your object. For example, consider the case where you have the following setup:

```ruby
class Blackboard
  belongs_to :classroom
end

class Classroom
  has_many :blackboards
end
```

Now let's say you just obtained a blackboard object from the params hash. If you want to make sure that the blackboard object is in the ``@classroom.blackboards`` association only once, you have to do a manual check to make sure you don't add it a second time.

```ruby 
blackboard = Blackboard.find(params[:id])
blackboard.modify_in_some_way!

unless @classroom.blackboards.include?(blackboard)
   @classroom.blackboards << blackboard
end
```

The new function I added allows you to boil the code down to:
```ruby
@classroom.blackboards.push_if_absent(blackboard)
```

title: DB with postgres string array column doesn't load fixtures well
body:
I have a rails4 app that uses a model with a string array column.  When I have a fixture that includes a string with a ' (single-quote) mark I get a syntax error when the fixtures attempt to load.  

To reproduce:

    git clone https://github.com/cconstantine/wattle.git
    cd wattle
    bundle install
    git checkout -b use_fixtures origin/use_fixtures
    rake db:create db:migrate db:test:prepare
    rspec

You can see an example of the exception output I see at:
https://gist.github.com/cconstantine/d4df1f2b29f92058badc

I've attached a commit that fixes it for me (although master appears to be broken right now).  I'm not sure if that's the best way to approach the problem, but it works for me and doesn't break any tests.  

Thanks

title: Fix regression re: #new with an STI object & complex inheritance
body:
Test case fails on the current master branch, but works on 3-2-stable.

Calling #subclasses [here](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/activerecord/lib/active_record/inheritance.rb#L177) only catches the direct children, which causes creating a new complex subclass to fail.

title: Refactoring the selector.rb file for the HTML sanitizer
body:
Right now, the HTML sanitizer is incredibly hard to read. This PR is a small step towards making it better. 

A lot of the code that was used in the ``Selector`` class was repeated. I've refactored some of this code into new protected helper methods. The ``concatenate_subset_to_matches!`` method refactors code that was basically copy and pasted in 3 different locations. 

I've also changed some ``for`` loops into ``each`` blocks, since in ``for`` loops, the iterator variable persists after the loop has been completed. There's no reason to do this in the ``match`` method (since those variables aren't used later).

title: Updated the error message for find to stay consistent across Rails
body:
The ``RecordNotFound`` error message that is raised when using ``find`` on an association which has ``inverse_of`` defined does not match the error message that is thrown for non-inverse-of associations. 

I've changed the error message to stay consistent with the error thrown for ``find`` without an
inverse_of association.

I also removed some variables that were not needed in the test cases related to the ``RecordNotFound`` error messages.

title: Fixes skipping object callback filters
body:
This allows you to skip callbacks that are defined by objects, e.g. for
`ActionController`:

    skip_after_filter MySpecialFilter

Previously this didn't work due to a bug in how Rails compared callbacks
in `Callback#matches?`. When a callback is compiled, if it's an object
filter (i.e. not a method, proc, etc.), `Callback` now defines a method on
`@klass` that is derived from the class name rather than `@callback_id`.
So, when `skip_callback` tries to find the appropriate callback to
remove, `Callback` can regenerate the method name for the filter
object and return the correct value for `Callback#matches?`.

title: Fixes #9654. Revert rendering behavior when format is unknown
body:
If a request has unknown format (eg. /foo.bar), the renderer
fallbacks to default format.

This patch reverts Rails 3.2 behavior after c2267db commit.

Fixes issue #9654.

title: Refactor render_to_string so it's a little shorter and simpler.
Throwing a RecordNotFound exception when a record is scanned using the inverse_of option
body:
This issue https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/10019 cropped up after I made the following change: https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/840ca09.  The change makes it so that if the ``:inverse_of`` option is specified on an association, then ActiveRecord will first check the in-memory association cache for the record before going to the database when ``find()`` is called. However, this not longer throws a ``RecordNotFound`` exception.

In this PR, I'm changing the behavior so that ``RecordNotFound`` is thrown in the correct circumstances. I've also refactored the code in the ``FindersMethod`` module so that it can be reused in the new check I've made.

title: Make references with index:true pass Hash options to add_index
body:
The definition for `ActiveRecord::ConnectionAdapters::SchemaStatements::TableDefinition#add_index` looks like

```ruby
add_index(table_name, column_name, options = {})
```

This can lead plugin writers to assume that `options` will always be a Hash, which has worked well so far.

This change makes the assumption hold when `TableDefinition#references` receives an `index` option set to `true`. I think the few extra hashes created during migrations are well worth not breaking 3rd-party code that relies on the Hash assumption, and I hope that you will agree with me.

Example of broken plugin: https://github.com/dazuma/activerecord-postgis-adapter/pull/60

I hope the test I added is alright, and I'll be happy to change it based on feedback.
